message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest carcinoid syndrome, which is caused by carcinoid tumors. The flushing, wheezing, loose stools, and right ventricular dysfunction are all characteristic of carcinoid syndrome. The CT findings of tumors also support this diagnosis. Systemic mastocytosis can also cause flushing and wheezing but does not typically lead to right ventricular dysfunction. Whipple’s disease and Irritable bowel syndrome are not associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of symptoms, including loose stools, palpitations, flushed appearance, and mid-calf edema, suggest carcinoid syndrome. The CT findings of small intestine and liver masses also support this diagnosis. Systemic mastocytosis may present with similar symptoms but is less likely given the CT findings. Whipple’s disease is very rare and presents with diarrhea and malabsorption, but not typical symptoms of carcinoid syndrome. Irritable bowel syndrome does not explain the other symptoms, such as palpitations and edema.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including loose stools, palpitations, and right ventricular dysfunction, suggest a carcinoid syndrome. The CT scan findings are also consistent with carcinoid tumors. Systemic mastocytosis could cause flushing and wheezing but not right ventricular dysfunction. Whipple’s disease would have gastrointestinal symptoms but not right ventricular dysfunction. Irritable bowel syndrome does not typically cause right ventricular dysfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of loose stools, palpitations, and non-pitting edema suggests carcinoid syndrome, which is caused by carcinoid tumors. The echocardiography findings also suggest carcinoid syndrome, as serotonin released by carcinoid tumors can cause right ventricular dysfunction. The CT scans show masses in the small intestine and liver, which can be indicative of carcinoid tumors. Systemic mastocytosis would have mast cell infiltration and Whipple's disease would have malabsorption, neither of which are noted in this patient. Irritable bowel syndrome would not cause the combination of symptoms seen in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of carcinoid syndrome, which includes flushing, wheezing, palpitations, and edema. The presence of a mass in the small intestine and liver suggests a carcinoid tumor. Systemic mastocytosis would also cause flushing and edema, but not the other symptoms. Whipple’s disease and irritable bowel syndrome do not explain the patient’s cardiac symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including diarrhea, flushing, wheezing, and a grade 2/6 murmur at the left mid-sternal area that is louder during inspiration, suggest carcinoid syndrome. The CT scan also shows masses in the small intestine and liver, which can be associated with carcinoid tumors. Systemic mastocytosis can cause flushing, but not the other symptoms. Whipple’s disease can cause diarrhea, but not the other symptoms. Irritable bowel syndrome does not explain the other symptoms, especially the cardiac manifestations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of flushing, wheezing, and edema along with a holosystolic murmur suggest carcinoid syndrome. CT findings of masses in the small intestine and liver are consistent with carcinoid tumors. Systemic mastocytosis would have skin findings such as diffuse redness and blistering, along with gastrointestinal symptoms. Whipple’s disease is marked by diarrhea, joint pain, and neurological dysfunction. Irritable bowel syndrome does not explain the patient’s other symptoms such as palpitations and right ventricular dysfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest carcinoid syndrome, including flushing, wheezes, and right ventricular dysfunction. The presence of small intestine and liver masses supports the diagnosis of carcinoid tumor, which can secrete vasoactive substances that cause the symptoms of carcinoid syndrome. None of the other options are likely to cause the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest carcinoid syndrome, which is caused by the release of vasoactive substances from neuroendocrine tumors like those found in the small intestine and liver. This can lead to flushing, diarrhea, wheezing, and right heart failure. The other conditions listed do not fit with the patient's symptoms and findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of carcinoid syndrome including flushing, wheezing, and diarrhea. The holosystolic murmur and right ventricular dysfunction are likely due to carcinoid heart disease, which can occur in patients with metastatic carcinoid tumors. The CT findings of masses in the small intestine and liver support the diagnosis of carcinoid tumor. Systemic mastocytosis, Whipple’s disease, and irritable bowel syndrome are less likely given the patient's presentation and findings.
